Some key characteristics of Actinopolyspora mzabensis include:

1. Colony morphology: The colonies are circular, convex, and yellowish-white in color.

2. Cell morphology: The cells are rod-shaped and occur singly or in short chains.

3. Chemotaxonomy: The cell wall contains meso-diaminopimelic acid, which is a characteristic feature of the cell wall composition of actinobacteria. The predominant menaquinone is MK-9(H4).

4. Physiological properties: Actinopolyspora mzabensis is halotolerant, capable of growing in the presence of up to 20% (w/v) NaCl. It is also capable of hydrolyzing various substrates, such as casein, gelatin, and starch.

5. Phylogenetic analysis: Based on 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis, Actinopolyspora mzabensis is closely related to other members of the genus Actinopolyspora, which are known to inhabit saline environments.

This species was first described in 2010 and is considered a novel member of the genus Actinopolyspora, contributing to the diversity of actinobacteria found in arid and saline environments.
